deliberation: Checked the standard prophetic formula וַיְהִי דְבַר־יְהוָה אֵלַי לֵאמֹר. Although conventional, it still treats the 'word' as an agent that can 'come' to the prophet, which is a mild personification/metaphor for revelatory experience.

instances.english_text: The word of GOD came to me
vehicle: a 'word' that comes to a person
ground: initiative from outside, directed to a recipient
instances.explanation: Divine revelation is depicted as a concrete 'word' that travels and arrives, personifying God's message as an agent that comes to the prophet.

deliberation: Considered 'son of man' (vocative title, largely lexicalized), 'end has come' (possible personification), and 'four corners of the land/earth' which is a well-known idiom/merism for the whole territory. Chose two distinct expressions: personification of 'end' and the meristic idiom 'four corners of the land.'

instances.english_text: Doom! Doom is coming
vehicle: a person/agent who comes or arrives
ground: sudden arrival, inevitability, approach toward the addressee
instances.explanation: The 'end' or 'doom' is portrayed as something that comes like an approaching person or force, personifying the abstract moment of judgment.

instances.english_text: upon the four corners of the land
target: the total territory affected (land of Israel)
vehicle: a four-cornered object with edges or wings
ground: completeness in all directions, full coverage
instances.explanation: The idiom 'four corners of the land/earth' functions as a merism, using the image of a four-cornered object to represent the whole territory in all directions.

deliberation: Looked at 'the end is upon you', 'I will let loose my anger' and 'I will put upon you all your abominations'. Found (1) anger expressed via the idiom 'my nose' being 'sent', combining metonymy and metaphor, and (2) their abominations being 'put upon' them as a metaphor of sin returning as burden/punishment.

instances.english_text: I will let loose My anger against you
vehicle: a nose or face that is thrust/let loose
ground: sudden, forceful expression, directed against someone
instances.explanation: Hebrew 'my nose' (אַפִּי) stands metonymically for anger, and this anger is depicted as something that can be 'sent out' or unleashed against them, personifying the emotion as an attacking force.

instances.english_text: I will requite you for all your abominations (lit. 'I will put upon you all your abominations')
target: the punitive consequences Judah will suffer
vehicle: a load or burden placed upon someone
physical weight laid on a body
ground: what one has produced becomes a weight borne by oneself
instances.explanation: Their own abominations are conceptualized as a burden that God places back on them, a metaphor for their sins returning as oppressive consequences.

deliberation: Focused on 'my eye will not spare' and 'your ways I will give upon you'. Both expressions extend bodily or spatial imagery to moral/judicial concepts. Identified (1) 'eye' as metonym for compassion and (2) 'ways upon you I will give' as retributive metaphor.

instances.english_text: I will show you no pity (lit. 'my eye shall not spare you')
vehicle: an eye that has or withholds pity
ground: the eye as indicator of favor or disdain
seeing with kindness vs. turning away
instances.explanation: The 'eye' stands metonymically for compassionate regard; saying the eye will not spare is an idiomatic way of saying no mercy will be shown.

instances.english_text: for I will requite you for your ways (lit. 'your ways I will give upon you')
vehicle: paths/ways being placed back upon a person
physical route as burden or outcome
ground: one's chosen path circles back upon oneself
instances.explanation: Their behavior ('ways') is pictured as something God can place back upon them, a metaphor depicting judgment as their own conduct returning as their fate.

deliberation: Language is compressed: 'A disaster, a singular disaster—behold, it comes.' The key figurative feature is the disaster as an entity that 'comes', i.e., a personified calamity approaching.

instances.english_text: A singular disaster; a disaster is coming
vehicle: a person or force that comes/approaches
ground: movement toward the addressee, inevitability, closeness
instances.explanation: The calamity is portrayed as if it were a personal agent that 'comes', personifying the disaster to intensify its imminence.

deliberation: Key expressions: 'end has come', 'it awakens against you'. The verb הֵקִיץ ('awoke') applied to קֵץ ('end') clearly personifies the 'end' as a sleeper rousing itself to attack.

instances.english_text: The hour of doom is coming! It stirs against you
target: the moment of judgment on the nation
vehicle: a sleeper awakening and moving against someone
ground: sudden transition from inactivity to active hostility
instances.explanation: The 'end' is depicted as a sleeper that awakens and rises up against them, personifying the abstract timing of judgment as an active assailant.

deliberation: Assessed the rare term הַצְּפִירָה ('the turn/doom'), the 'day' language, and 'panic on the mountains, not joy.' Took הַצְּפִירָה בָּאָה as personification of a cycle/turn of fate, and 'panic on the mountains' as metonymic for the terror of those dwelling there.

instances.english_text: The cycle has come around for you, O inhabitants of the land
target: the appointed turn of judgment against the land
vehicle: a turning or cycle that comes toward someone
ground: inevitable return of a cycle to its starting point
inescapable arrival at a destined moment
posture: prophetic framing of history as cyclical
instances.explanation: The term for 'turn/doom' is portrayed as something that 'comes' to the inhabitants, personifying the fateful cycle of judgment as an approaching entity.

instances.english_text: There is panic on the mountains, not joy
target: the terrified people in the mountainous regions
ground: mountains stand for those dwelling on them
shared fate of land and people
instances.explanation: The 'mountains' function metonymically for their inhabitants: saying panic is on the mountains means those who live there are in panic rather than joy.

deliberation: Examined 'I will pour out my wrath' and 'I will exhaust/spend my anger.' Both use physical imagery for divine emotion: wrath as a liquid poured and anger as something that can be used up.

instances.english_text: Very soon I will pour out My wrath upon you
target: God's punitive fury against the people
vehicle: a liquid being poured out from a container
ground: intensity of outflow, loss of restraint
being engulfed by what is poured
instances.explanation: Wrath is conceptualized as a liquid that God can pour out on them, conveying overwhelming, unrestrained judgment.

instances.english_text: and spend My anger on you
target: duration and extent of God's anger
vehicle: a finite resource that can be used up/consumed
ground: anger has a limit that, once reached, ends in complete outpouring
instances.explanation: God's anger is depicted as something that can be 'finished' or used up, a metaphor of emotional wrath as a finite resource consumed in judgment.

deliberation: Parallels verse 4 in phrasing: 'my eye will not spare,' 'your ways upon you I will give.' Identified same two figurative patterns: 'eye' as metonym for compassion and 'ways upon you' as retributive metaphor, with the added self-revelatory formula 'I, YHWH, who strike.'

instances.english_text: I will show you no pity and no compassion (lit. 'my eye will not spare')
vehicle: the eye as sparing or not sparing
ground: looking with favor equated with mercy; refusal to 'spare with the eye' equals lack of compassion
instances.explanation: Again the 'eye' functions metonymically for God's compassionate regard; to say the eye does not spare is an idiomatic way of saying He will not show pity.

instances.english_text: I will requite you for your ways (lit. 'according to your ways I will give upon you')
target: the punishment that comes on the people
vehicle: a gift or object placed upon someone matching their path
ground: what one has done returns proportionally as what one receives
fit correspondence between act and result
instances.explanation: Judgment is described as 'giving' their own ways back upon them, using the language of transaction to depict moral reciprocity.

deliberation: This verse is densely figurative: 'the day has come', 'the cycle/doom has gone out', 'the rod has blossomed', 'arrogance has budded.' I distinguish (1) the personified 'cycle' going out, and (2) the rod blossoming, and (3) arrogance budding like a plant as separate but related metaphors.

instances.english_text: the cycle has come round; it has appeared (lit. 'the doom/turn has gone out')
target: the activation of the decreed judgment
vehicle: something or someone going out from a place
ground: transition from hidden to public action
instances.explanation: The 'turn/doom' is pictured as something that 'goes out', like an army or herald, personifying the decree as an active emissary of judgment.

instances.english_text: The rod has blossomed
target: the instrument of punishment arising from social evil
vehicle: a rod that sprouts or blossoms like a plant
ground: development from earlier latent stage to full effectiveness
maturation of something that was present but dormant
posture: prophetic explanation of how judgment arose
instances.explanation: The 'rod' (symbol of punishment) is said to have blossomed, likening the emergence of the punitive power to a branch reaching full growth.

instances.english_text: arrogance has budded
vehicle: a plant that buds or flowers
ground: incremental growth from hidden root to visible flower
instances.explanation: Arrogance is described as a plant that has budded, portraying their insolence as having grown to a conspicuous and ripe stage.

deliberation: The central image is 'violence has risen into a rod of wickedness.' It continues the rod imagery but with a distinct formulation: moral violence is pictured as being forged into a punitive rod.

instances.english_text: lawlessness has grown into a rod of wickedness
vehicle: a rod of wickedness that rises up
ground: their own violence becomes the very instrument that strikes them
instances.explanation: Their violence is personified and metaphorically transformed into a 'rod of wickedness' that rises, implying that their own wrongdoing becomes the rod that will beat them.

deliberation: Looked for figurative devices: 'the time has come, the day has arrived' functions more as temporal proclamation; buyer/seller emotions are literal; 'wrath against all her multitude' is standard but not strongly figurative here. I judge the verse largely straightforward.

Considered 'seller shall not return to what was sold' (literal in siege context), and 'the vision ... shall not return' (a prophecy 'returning' is non-literal; it is personified as something that could go back). Decided that this is a clear personification/metaphor of the prophetic vision as an irrevocable agent.

instances.english_text: For the vision concerns all her multitude, it shall not be revoked (lit. 'shall not return')
target: the prophetic declaration of coming judgment
vehicle: an entity that could return or go back on its path
ground: irrevocability, non-reversal once set in motion
instances.explanation: The 'vision' is treated as if it were something that could go back but refuses to, personifying the prophetic word as an irreversible agent.

deliberation: The trumpet and battle imagery are literal within war context. The main non-literal element is 'My wrath is against all her multitude' (חֲרוֹנִי), where 'burning' stands idiomatically for anger.

instances.english_text: for My wrath is directed against all her multitude
vehicle: burning heat (חֲרוֹן) as a state directed toward someone
ground: heat as experiential analog of anger's intensity
burning and consuming character of wrath
instances.explanation: The noun 'burning' (חֲרוֹן) is a metonymy for anger, using the experience of heat to represent the intensity of God's wrath toward the people.

deliberation: War, pestilence, and famine form a typical triad. The explicit figurative expression is 'famine and pestilence shall devour him'—where non-personal agents are said to 'eat' people.

instances.english_text: famine and pestilence shall devour him
target: the lethal effects of famine and plague on city-dwellers
vehicle: a predator or eater devouring its prey
instances.explanation: Famine and pestilence are personified as devouring agents, likened to a predator eating its victim to convey their deadly thoroughness.

deliberation: The primary figure is explicit: 'they shall be like doves of the valleys, all of them moaning.' This simile compares survivors to moaning doves. The rest is literal confession ('each for his iniquity').

instances.hebrew_text: וְהָי֣וּ אֶל־הֶהָרִ֗ים כְּיוֹנֵ֧י הַגֵּאָי֛וֹת כֻּלָּ֖ם הֹמ֑וֹת
instances.english_text: they shall take to the mountains; they shall be like doves of the valley, moaning together
target: the terrified human survivors fleeing to the hills
vehicle: doves of the valleys that moan
ground: fearful, plaintive sounds; vulnerability; clustering in elevated refuges
instances.explanation: The survivors are explicitly likened to valley-doves that continually moan, emphasizing their fear, frailty, and mournful cries.

deliberation: Both clauses depict emotional collapse through bodily imagery: 'all hands shall become weak' and 'all knees shall go as water.' Treated them as two related but distinct metaphors/idioms for terror-induced loss of strength.

instances.english_text: All hands shall grow weak
ground: terror removes ability to act effectively
instances.explanation: The idiom of hands becoming weak uses physical limpness as a metaphor for loss of strength and resolve under extreme fear.

instances.english_text: and all knees shall turn to water
target: stability and firmness in the face of danger
vehicle: knees becoming like or flowing with water
ground: utter loss of firmness; trembling or collapsing
instances.explanation: The phrase depicts knees as if they become water—an idiomatic metaphor for extreme fear that removes all stability and control.

deliberation: Sackcloth and baldness function as literal mourning customs. Two non-literal elements stand out: 'horror shall cover them' and 'shame on every face,' where emotions are portrayed as garments or coverings.

instances.english_text: and horror shall cover them
vehicle: a covering or garment that envelops someone
instances.explanation: Horror is depicted as something that physically covers them like a garment, metaphorically expressing how utterly they are enveloped by fear.

instances.english_text: every face shall betray shame (lit. 'on all faces, shame')
vehicle: a visible layer or mark on the face
ground: shame as something resting on one's countenance
facial expression as sign of inner state
instances.explanation: Shame is treated as something that rests upon their faces, a metaphor for how their disgrace will be unmistakably visible.

deliberation: Several figurative elements: wealth as unable to 'save' in the day of wrath, silver/gold counted as נִדָּה (ritual impurity), and 'stumbling-block of their iniquity.' I isolate (1) wealth becoming 'unclean' and (2) 'stumbling-block of their iniquity' as distinct, well-formed metaphors/idioms.

instances.english_text: their gold shall be treated as something unclean
vehicle: ritually unclean thing (נִדָּה), associated with impurity and avoidance
ground: what was valued becomes repulsive and untouchable
inversion of status from prized to defiled
posture: critique of idolatrous trust in riches
instances.explanation: Gold is metaphorically recategorized as 'menstrual impurity' or defilement (נִדָּה), signaling that their wealth has become morally contaminating rather than honorable.

instances.english_text: Because they made them stumble into guilt (lit. 'for it was the stumbling-block of their iniquity')
target: their silver and gold (or what they did with them)
vehicle: a stumbling-block that causes one to trip
ground: transition from safe walking to collapse
instances.explanation: Their wealth (and its idolatrous use) is called 'the stumbling-block of their iniquity,' an idiomatic metaphor for something that trips them up spiritually and leads to sin.

deliberation: Focused on 'the beauty of his ornament' and especially 'I will make it to them for uncleanness (לְנִדָּה).' This continues the metaphor of valuables (probably temple adornments) becoming ritual pollution.

instances.english_text: therefore I will make their adornments a source of uncleanness to them
ground: close association brings defilement instead of honor
reversal of value from glory to shame
what they worshiped now harms them
instances.explanation: God declares He will turn their prized adornments into 'uncleanness' for them, continuing the metaphor of valuable objects becoming sources of ritual and moral pollution.

deliberation: This verse describes giving the valuables 'into the hand of strangers' and their being 'profaned.' These are standard terms for conquest and desecration, functioning largely literally in the context, so I do not mark a distinct figurative device beyond normal cultic language.

Main non-literal expression: 'I will turn my face from them.' 'Face' here stands for God's favorable presence; turning it away is a metaphor for withdrawing protection. The rest (treasures/holy place defiled by intruders) is within literal cultic-desecration language.

instances.english_text: I will turn My face from them
target: God's favorable attention and protective presence
vehicle: a face turned toward or away from someone
ground: turning one's face away signals rejection, ceasing engagement
face-toward as favor, face-away as abandonment
instances.explanation: God's 'face' functions as a metonym for His favorable presence; turning it away metaphorically describes His withdrawal of attentive protection.

deliberation: Two imagery layers: 'make/forge the chain' (literal order anticipating captivity) and 'the land is full of bloodshed; the city is full of violence'—using container imagery and 'land/city' metonymically for their inhabitants. I mark the fullness and land/city usage as one composite figurative instance.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּ֣י הָאָ֗רֶץ מָֽלְאָה֙ מִשְׁפַּ֣ט דָּמִ֔ים וְהָעִ֖יר מָלְאָ֥ה חָמָֽס
instances.english_text: for the land is full of bloody crimes, and the city is full of lawlessness
target: the moral condition of the people living in the land and city
vehicle: a land/city as a container filled with a substance
physical volume holding liquid or objects
ground: pervasiveness and saturation of violence and injustice
instances.explanation: The 'land' and 'city' stand metonymically for their inhabitants, and are depicted as containers 'full' of bloodshed and violence, an exaggerated image of pervasive moral corruption.

deliberation: Key phrase: 'I will put an end to the pride of the strong' (וְהִשְׁבַּתִּי גְּאוֹן עַזִּים). Here 'pride of the strong' functions as a metonym for the arrogant powerful, and 'cause to cease' uses quasi-locutional imagery of shutting down a sound or activity.

instances.english_text: so shall I turn to naught the pride of the powerful
target: the arrogant elite and their self-exaltation
vehicle: 'pride' as a quality that can be ceased
ground: removal of public display of arrogance equates to downfall of the arrogant
instances.explanation: The expression 'pride of the strong' stands metonymically for the arrogant powerful themselves; God 'causing it to cease' portrays their fall as the end of their arrogant display.

deliberation: The noun קְפָדָה ('horror/destruction') is said to 'come'; thus an abstract terror is personified as an approaching entity. 'They will seek peace, and there shall be none' is more conceptual than imaginative.

instances.english_text: Horror comes
vehicle: a person or force that comes/arrives
ground: sudden arrival and presence, unavoidable encounter
posture: compression of threat into one word
instances.explanation: The abstract 'horror/destruction' is personified as something that comes, making the terror of judgment feel like an approaching entity.

deliberation: Noted: 'calamity upon calamity, rumor upon rumor' as piling repetition, and 'instruction shall perish from priest, counsel from elders' where abstract entities 'perish.' I mark (1) the repeated calamity/rumor as hyperbolic accumulation and (2) Torah/counsel perishing as personification.

instances.hebrew_text: הֹוָ֤ה עַל־הֹוָה֙ תָּב֔וֹא וּשְׁמֻעָ֥ה אֶל־שְׁמוּעָ֖ה תִּֽהְיֶ֑ה
instances.english_text: Calamity shall follow calamity, and rumor follow rumor
target: frequency and intensity of bad events and news
instances.explanation: The doubling 'calamity upon calamity, rumor upon rumor' is a hyperbolic idiom stressing the relentless succession of disasters and disturbing reports.

instances.english_text: instruction shall perish from the priest, and counsel from the elders
ground: end of capacity to provide what they once did
instances.explanation: Torah and counsel, abstractions, are personified as things that 'perish,' picturing the loss of guidance as a kind of death.

deliberation: Important image: 'the prince shall clothe himself with desolation.' Here 'desolation' is treated as a garment. The other clauses ('hands will tremble', retributive 'according to their way') are more standard though they echo earlier metaphors.

instances.english_text: the prince shall clothe himself with desolation
target: the prince's experience of utter ruin and grief
vehicle: a garment of desolation worn on the body
ground: being entirely enveloped in ruin and grief
instances.explanation: Desolation is depicted as the prince's clothing, an idiomatic metaphor conveying that his whole appearance and condition will be marked by ruin.
